items.content: FLIGHT 17: The Malaysia Airlines flight was downed by a surface-to-air missile on July 17 in a separatist-controlled corner of eastern Ukraine. The Boeing 777 was traveling from Amsterdam to Kuala Lumpur.

TRADING BLAME: On July 22, the Obama administration detailed what it called evidence of Russian complicity in the downing of the airliner. Right after the crash, Ukrainian government and rebels had pointed the finger at each other, and Russian President Vladimir Putin indirectly accused Kiev, but the United States and West had been circumspect about assigning blame.

THE UKRAINIAN CONFLICT: Ukraine’s then-president made a move in November toward Russia and away from Europe. That led to protests that forced him out and raised tensions between the Russia-leaning east of the country and the Europe-leaning west. The U.S.-backed government in Kiev and Russia-supported separatists have been engaged in a shooting war for months.
MALAYSIA AIRLINES AGAIN: MH370 went missing March 8 en route from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing. That case is still unsolved, though there is suspicion of criminal activity.

SANCTIONS:  The European Union unleashed tough economic sanctions on Russia on July 29, a move designed to push Moscow into backing down from its destabilizing role in eastern Ukraine. The United States was expected to announce more sanctions as well.

WHAT’S AT STAKE: Nearly 300 people from many nations were killed. Sanctions could inflict serious damage on the Russian economy, which relies heavily on Europe  as a market for its oil and gas, as a source of financing and as a supplier of components for its military.

items.headline: Sanctions could cause pain in Europe, too
